column1: Preeclampsia is high blood pressure and protein in the urine after the 20th week of pregnancy.
You may need to take medicines to lower your blood pressure.
DO NOT take any extra vitamins, calcium, aspirin, or other medicines without talking with your provider first.
Often, women who have preeclampsia do not feel sick or have any symptoms.
There are risks to both you and your baby if you develop preeclampsia: - The mother can have kidney damage, seizures, stroke, or bleeding in the liver.

Call your health care provider right away if you: - Have swelling in your hands, face, or eyes (edema) - Suddenly gain weight over 1 or 2 days, or you gain more than 2 pounds in a week - Have a headache that does not go away or becomes worse - Are not urinating very often - Have nausea and vomiting - Have vision changes, such as you cannot see for a short time, see flashing lights or spots, are sensitive to light, or have blurry vision - Feel light-headed or faint - Have pain in your belly below your ribs - Have pain in your right shoulder - Have problems breathing - Bruise easily
